title: Captains call players-only meeting
text:
Baker Mayfield lit up Kansas State’s defense for five touchdowns passes and the Oklahoma defense intercepted three passes as the Sooners made the Wildcats look lifeless on Saturday. 
Sometimes it means more coming from your peers. 
At least that’s what is appears the Kansas State football captains were going for when they called a players-only meeting Monday afternoon to discuss the state of the season — just 48 hours after being throttled by 55 points at home against Oklahoma. 
“The captains called it and led the discussion,” junior linebacker Will Davis said Tuesday. “They’re taking the initiative and showing their leadership ability, trying to figure out what the problem is and get it corrected.” 
There is a lot that needs corrected after getting shut out last Saturday — the first for a Wildcat team since 1996 — and now only three days out from K-State’s next challenge this weekend against the Longhorns in Austin, Texas. 
Across the board, K-State was pretty bad last Saturday — offensively, defensively and special teams — just a week removed from taking then-No. 2 TCU down the wire in a seven-point loss. 
“I thought we had a good week of practice last week,” Davis said of the preparation leading up to OU. “I thought we prepared well and the coaches put us in the right places. We just didn’t execute. That’s what it came down to. (Oklahoma) came to play and we didn’t. 
“I’ve never been through a game like that, where you get flat-out embarrassed in front of everyone, in front of the world. Nobody wants go through something like that again.” 
Monday’s players’ meeting certainly seems to have been a first step in healing Saturday’s deep wound. 
“It was pretty much, ‘we need to get on the same page because we have a lot of games left and we can finish with a good record still,” junior offensive lineman Terrale Johnson said. “The captains told everyone we can’t be hanging our heads and we need to move forward — a positive thing so we keep rolling. 
“I thought it was real positive.” 
Davis said a players-only meeting is commonplace when the season starts, but he couldn’t recall one during a season and certainly not with the tone of Monday’s gathering. 
Urgency has set in — that was evident at Monday’s practice. 
“I think it did carry over into practice,” he said. “Some of the things that were said carried over into practice and helped keep some guys focused. I think it really benefited us.” 
Only time will tell, but what is known is that K-State has lost three straight games and has a daunting matchup at home with Baylor looming on Nov. 5. The worst-case scenario for the Wildcats right now would be for this three-game skid to turn into four and then five straight losses. 
The last K-State time lost three straight Big 12 games was the 2013 season before finishing the year on a hot streak and a win in the Buffalo Wild Wings Bowl. 
Can this season’s Wildcats do the same? 
Monday’s meeting was about doing just that, before it’s too late. 
“It was about keeping guys’ minds on the right track and where they’re supposed to be,” Davis said. “It was to let guys talk about little bit about how they feel about the season, how we should practice, more of a motivational meeting than anything.”
